title: Banu Qasi

common.text:
بنو قسي

The family Banu Qasi in Arabic language.

The Banu Qasi, descendants of Qasi, have their origins among the Visigoths (Fernández, Juan G., , pp. 25 ; Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 6-7 ; Medieval Lands, , Moorish Spain), they maintained control over a region after the fall of the Visigothic kings (History Tracers, , Visigodos). While it is difficult to establish connections between Visigothic kings and other Iberian kings, we have well-documented relationships between Banu Qasi descendants and other kings. However, there are also some hypotheses presented as theories, which we mention below

Knowledge never stops, and here we are not presenting the entire history of the Banu Qasi. To learn more about them, in addition to the chronicles and papers we mention, we suggest visiting the site Medieval Lands (Medieval Lands, Moorish Spain)

This text is part of the level "The person name is..." in the game Scientific method by History Tracers. We recommend that readers play at least this level to see a practical application of the scientific method

maps.text: Map of the Iberian Peninsula highlighting the region dominated by the Banu Qasi during their peak between and (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 29). The delimited area is shown approximately to provide the reader with a clearer understanding

prerequisites: There are no additional prerequisites to understand this text.

history.text: This family possibly originated with Qasi, who converted to Islam at the beginning of the Arab conquest of the Iberian Peninsula (De La Granja, Fernando , , pp. 86; ; Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 7 ; Medieval Lands, )

We must highlight some points raised in Jesús Lorenzo Jiménez's work about Qasi's possible life (Jiménez, Jesús L., ):

  • Pages 174 - 175: In , Qasi was referred to as Cássio for the first time (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 6). There are no documents or chronicles that mention him directly.
  • Page 178: Despite the lack of documentation, his lineage continued until the 10th century.
  • Page 180: There is a possibility that: "este conde Casio no es sino un personaje mítico" [translation: this Count Cássio is nothing but a mythical character].

Reflection 2: About descendants
When you read in a paper that a family lineage continued until the "10th century", do you understand that this means there are known generations up to the present day?

Ibn Hazm names Qasi as the Count of Marca and also mentions his five children (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 86; Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, ). We will consider these children as real and not just hypothetical, because as Jesús Lorenzo Jiménez concluded: "Casio existía" [translation: Casio existed ] (Jiménez, Jesús L., , pp. 180)
According to Al-Udri (De la Granja, Fernando, , pp. 86; Juste, Alberto c., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al-Udri (De la Granja, Fernando, , pp. 86; Juste, Alberto c., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al-Udri (De la Granja, Fernando, , pp. 86; Juste, Alberto c., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al-Udri (De la Granja, Fernando, , pp. 86; Juste, Alberto c., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al-Udri (De la Granja, Fernando, , pp. 86; Juste, Alberto c., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, )

He was the only son named with a Christian name (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 7; Medieval Lands, ).

We do not have more details about his life. We only know that he had two children, listed below. Some researchers propose a name for his wife, but there is no documentation to support this hypothesis.

Reflection 3: About marriages
The hypothetical marriage of Fortún with Aisha, seems to be based on the fact that Fortún had a son named Musa, like the conqueror Musa ibn Nusayr.
Is having a son with the same name enough to establish a connection?
Could the Qasi have chosen the name because they were Muslims?
Could it be that the name was chosen in honor of another ancestor of Fortún?
Can you propose other hypotheses?

Creating hypotheses is part of the scientific method, but a hypothesis only becomes a theory, or a fact, when there is evidence to support it (History Tracers, , Scientific method)

Although there are no documents or chronicles from the time mentioning any wife or wives of Fortún ibn Qasi, it is possible to find references to such hypothetical connections in discussion groups (Google Groups, ) and articles on platforms (Wikipedia, , Fortún ibn Qasi)
According to Al-Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al-Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )

He is the first Banu Qasi documented in historical events by contemporaneous chronicles. According to these records, on , he was responsible for expelling the rebel Said ibn al-Ḥusayn Yahya from Zaragoza (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 9; Medieval Lands, ; Benito, Julia P., Real Academia de La Historia).

The exact date of his death is unknown, but it occurred either in or (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 9 - 10; De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 465; Medieval Lands, ).

Regarding his marriages, it is known that he married at least one woman who was also married to Iñigo (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 469; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 469; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 532; Medieval Lands, )

During Musa Ibn Musa's lifetime, the Banu Qasi reached their peak (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 12-35). However, this was not a calm period for him and his descendants. Musa Ibn Musa, for example, is noted as the first rebel of the family (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533).

?
On Rebellions
We are facing yet another rebellion. Can you imagine a reason for so many rebellions?

Since we are not dealing with a single rebellion, it is likely that there is more than one answer to this reflection. We remind the reader that one of the reasons the Arabs entered the Iberian Peninsula and defeated the Visigoths was an invitation from the local people (Ibn El-Kouthya, M. A. Cherbonneau, , pp. 8 - 9).

The Chronicle of Alfonso III provides the most relevant information related to the Gothic origin of the Qasi: "Muzza quidam nomine natione Gotus" [translation: A certain Musa by name, from the Gothic nation] (Fernández, Juan G., , pp. 25; Medieval Lands, )

The Codex of Roda informs us that Musa married Assona Iñiguez, daughter of Iñigo Arista (Lacarra, José M., , pp. 229; Medieval Lands, ). However, although this marriage is documented, there is insufficient evidence to identify their children. For this reason, we will attribute the children to an 'Unknown' person
According to Códice Roda (Lacarra, José M., , pp. 229; Medieval Lands, )
According to Medieval Lands (Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Ibn Hazm (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 471; Medieval Lands, )

During his governance, the Vikings ('Mayus') invaded the Iberian Peninsula. Lubb ibn Musa was taken captive, but after being freed by the Sultan, he fought against the invaders. In recognition of his efforts, the Sultan gifted him an enslaved person named Ayab (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 471 - 473; Medieval Lands, ).

Recently, in an attempt to justify a 'conversion' to Judaism of a person named Lopo (Dias, History Tracers), an author made claims without providing evidence or statistics about the name Lubb. For this reason, we use this historical figure to clarify some facts. Lubb is referred to as Lupus in Latin sources like the Chronicon Sebastiani (Flórez, Henriques, , p. 488) and in the Chronicle of Alfonso III (Fernández, Juan G., , pp. 9,16; Medieval Lands, ). In the latter chronicle, it is also mentioned that he was the governor of Toledo (Juste, Alberto C., , pp. 38). In Spanish his name is 'Lope' (Juste, Alberto C., ), and in Portuguese genealogical sites, he is referred to as 'Lopo' (Roglo, "Lopo ibn Musa ibn Musa (Banu Qasi)")

In addition to his documented sons, some researchers have recently suggested he had a daughter named Aurea. It is possible that this person was the wife of Fortún Garcia, but her mention in the Codex of Roda does not include her parents (Lacarra, José M., , pp. 230; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 473; Medieval Lands, )
According to citações em fórums (Google Groups, ; Wikipedia, , Fortún ibn Qasi)
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )

?
On Ancestry
Why are there so many attempts to link the Banu Qasi to individuals whose relationships cannot be proven?

It is likely that the Banu Qasi are receiving the same treatment as the Visigothic kings, in an attempt to create a continuous lineage (History Tracers, , Visigoths).

Like his ancestors, he was also a rebel. He entered the city of Zaragoza in the years - and took control of it, later selling it for "dez mil ...." [translation: ten thousand...] (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 478; Medieval Lands, ).

He was appointed governor of various regions by Imam Muhammad I. Loyal to the imam, he waged war against Pamplona, conquering much of the city (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 479; Medieval Lands, ).

The last war of Muhammad ibn Lubb took place in Arribal, where he laid a great siege to the city, raising a large wall around it. One day, while riding his horse, he decided to enter the ruins of the city, where a man on foot advanced and killed him with a spear (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 480; Medieval Lands, ).

Although there are reports of marriages from his sons and grandsons, there are no records of subsequent generations (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533 - 534; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to J. Lorenzo Jiménez research mentioned in Medieval Lands site (Medieval Lands, )

There is little information about his life, and what we have is not conclusive. Medieval Lands mentions that he could have been captured in a battle during the reign of Charlemagne, king of France (Medieval Lands, ).

The data about his descendants is also imprecise. According to Ibn Hazm, Musa ibn Musa, his brother, arranged marriages for his daughters with the sons of "Wannago ibn Sanyo, rey de los Vascos" [translation: Wannago ibn Sanyo, king of the Vascos] (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533). With this limited information, we can only speculate that the marriages might have been with Iñigo Iñíguez, Fortún Iñíguez, or possibly another undocumented son, but nothing beyond that. This information at least allows us to properly address Reflection 2. Due to the lack of details, claiming that the Banu Qasi have descendants in the present day is imprecise
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )
According to Al Udri (De La Granja, Fernando, , pp. 533; Medieval Lands, )

exercise_v2.question: Are the Banu Qasi descendants of Visigoths converted to Islam?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: This information is confirmed by the Chronicle of Alfonso III, written years after the events occurred. Recent research has not discarded this possibility.

exercise_v2.question: Is Fortún ibn Qasi the first documented Banu Qasi?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The first documented ancestor is his son, Musa ibn Fortun. We know who his ancestors are because Musa is identified as the son of Fortun (ibn Fortún). Both are known to be Banu Qasi (بنو قسي) [translation: descendants of Qasi], which we assume to be their oldest known ancestor.

exercise_v2.question: Were there different rebellions in the Iberian Peninsula in a short period of time?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Different chronicles written by various authors mention rebellions in the Iberian Peninsula.

exercise_v2.question: Like the Visigoth kings, can we not comfortably say that there are generations of Banu Qasi nowadays?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The limited information remaining does not allow us to confirm that there are present-day descendants, but there are indications that these generations could exist.

exercise_v2.question: Ancient chronicles mention the Banu Qasi as 'Goths', while we mention them as 'Visigoths'. Are we making a significant mistake here?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The Visigoths are a subgroup of the Goths (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, , Visigodos), so we are not making a mistake. The difference between the chronicles and the text is that we are specifically addressing the group of Goths who lived in the Iberian Peninsula.
